sen.j: 観賢（かんげん、斉衡元年（854年）- 延長 (元号)3年6月11日 (旧暦)（925年7月4日））は、平安時代中期の真言宗の僧。
sen.e: Kangen (854-July 4, 925) is a priest of the Shingon sect in the mid Heian Period.
Kangen (854-July 4, 925) was a priest of the Shingon sect during the mid Heian Period.
Kangen (854 - July 9, 925) was a priest of the Shingon sect during the mid Heian Period.

sen.j: 俗姓は秦氏とも伴氏ともされ、出自については不詳である。
sen.e: While his secular surname is alleged to be either Hata clan or Tomo clan, the details of his origin are not clear.
While his secular surname is alleged to be either Hata clan or Tomo clan, the details of his origin are not clear.

sen.j: 般若寺僧正とも称される。
sen.e: He is also known as Sojo of Hannya-ji Temple.
He is also known as Sojo of Hannya-ji Temple.
He is also known as Hannya-ji Sojo (high-ranking Buddhist priest at Hannya-ji Temple).
sen.cmt: 般若寺僧正 補足を追加しました。

sen.j: 貞観 (日本)14年（872年）真雅について出家・受戒し、聖宝より三論宗・真言密教の教学を学んで、寛平7年（895年）に灌頂を受けた。
sen.e: In 872, Kangen became priest and received the religious precepts under Shinga, studied the doctrines of Sanron Sect and Shingon Esoteric Buddhism under Shobo and went through Kanjo (the ceremony to be the successor) in 895.

sen.cmt: Sect 小文字にしました。

sen.j: 昌泰3年（900年）に仁和寺別当となる。
sen.e: In 900, he became betto (administrator) of Ninna-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In 900, he became betto (administrator) of Ninna-ji Temple.
In 900, he became betto (the head priest) of Ninna-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 別当→the head priest として統一しています。

sen.j: その後は川原寺別当・権律師・東寺長者・醍醐寺座主・金剛峯寺検校を歴任し、延長元年（923年）には権僧正に任じられた。
sen.e: After successively holding the positions of betto of Kawara-dera Temple, Gon-Risshi (generally in Shingon sect, fifteenth-ranking Buddhist priest, literally, "supernumerary master of discipline"), choja (chief abbot of the temple) of Higashi-dera Temple, zasu (a head priest of a temple) of Daigo-ji Temple, and kengyo (temple administrator) of Kongobu-ji Temple, Kangen was appointed in 923 as Gon no Sojo (the provisional lower priest in the highest position).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After successively holding the positions of betto of Kawara-dera Temple, Gon-Risshi (generally in Shingon sect, fifteenth-ranking Buddhist priest, literally, "supernumerary master of discipline"), choja (chief abbot of the temple) of Higashi-dera Temple, zasu (a head priest of a temple) of Daigo-ji Temple, and kengyo (temple administrator) of Kongobu-ji Temple, Kangen was appointed in 923 as Gon no Sojo (the provisional lower priest in the highest position).

After successively holding the positions of betto of Kawara-dera Temple, Gon no Risshi (generally in Shingon sect, 15th-ranking Buddhist priest, literally, "supernumerary master of discipline"), To-ji choja (the chief abbot of To-ji Temple), zasu (a head priest) of Daigo-ji Temple, and kengyo (temple administrator) of Kongobu-ji Temple, Kangen was appointed in 923 as Gon no Sojo (the provisional lower priest in the highest position).
sen.cmt: 役職名の補足を修正しました。

sen.j: この間、般若寺を創建し、また奏請して空海に弘法大師の号を賜った。
sen.e: In the meantime, Kangen founded Hannya-ji Temple, petitioned the emperor to award Kukai the title of Kobo Daishi.

sen.j: ほか、空海が唐から請来した「三十帖冊子」を東寺の経蔵に納めて以後代々の真言宗長者の相承とするなど、東寺を中心として真言宗の再編を行った。
sen.e: In addition, Kangen restructured Shingon Sect, based in Higashi-dera Temple, by storing in the Kyozo (sutra repository) the "Sanjujo Sasshi (thirty volumes of esoteric Buddhist scripture hand-copied by priest Kukai when he was staying in China)" brought back by Kukai from Tang Dynasty, and determining that the volumes should be taken after by choja of Shingon sect generations after generation.
